items.title: Syrian Refugees Strain Resources in Jordan
items.abstract: Despite plans by aid organizations to help at least 50,000 urban refugees, a large number will be left out because of the rising numbers of Syrians fleeing across the border each day.
keywords: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )

items.title: City Housing Projects Call For Environmental Help
items.abstract: Housing project residents say the city encouraged them to “go green,” but did little to help them and in some circumstances, stood in their way.

items.title: Hurricane Cost City at Least $154 Million in Overtime
items.abstract: Eighty-one percent of the total went to the Police and Sanitation Departments alone, according to a report released Friday by the Independent Budget Office.

items.title: Nashville’s Latest Big Hit Could Be the City Itself
items.abstract: The city, which sat on the sidelines while its Southern sisters boomed, has found itself in the national spotlight, with economic gains and a newly found popularity.

items.title: An Urban Standard, Coolly Reimagined
items.abstract: William Lescaze’s 1935 Kramer house, like many Modernist houses, is not weathering well.

items.title: As Cuomo Acts on Homeless Problem, New York City Blames State Cuts
items.abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo is only one player in addressing the issue in the city, but decisions his administration has made have left the city shouldering more of the burden.

items.title: Pritzker Prize for Architecture Is Awarded to Alejandro Aravena of Chile
items.abstract: Mr. Aravena, who has focused on low-cost social housing and reconstructing after natural disasters, received the honor as Chile emerges as a locus of noteworthy architecture.

items.title: The City Takes a Hit in Mr. Cuomo’s Budget
items.abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio must defend the city’s interests in any struggle over funds from the state budget.

items.title: Anger and Scrutiny Grow Over Poisoned Water in Michigan City
items.abstract: The state’s investigation into lead contamination of Flint’s drinking water follows the governor’s request that President Obama declare the problem a federal emergency.

items.title: On the Stockholm Waterfront, ‘Renewing a New City’
items.abstract: Sustainable housing plans have transformed Hammarby Sjostad, a neighborhood in Stockholm. Now, new cultural projects are providing another boost.

items.title: Where Did Rents Rise the Most in 2018?
items.abstract: Small American cities may not have the highest rents, but they did see the biggest percentage increases over the past year.

items.title: Judge Blocks New York City Law Aimed at Curbing Airbnb Rentals
items.abstract: The law was intended to prevent apartments from being used as illegal hotels. The decision could aid home-sharing services’ fights in other cities.

items.title: What’s Coming in New York Real Estate in 2019
items.abstract: An already soft market will get another 20,000 new apartments, making it an even stronger buyer’s and renter’s market.

items.title: How Cities Make Money by Fining the Poor
items.abstract: In many parts of America, like Corinth, Miss., judges are locking up defendants who can’t pay — sometimes for months at a time.

items.title: Some Workers Need Jobs as Much as Builders Need Workers. Cities Connect Them.
items.abstract: In tight labor markets, developers and local leaders are using major projects to provide residents with careers in construction.

items.title: Nashville Finds Opportunity in the Hole a Bomber Left in the Heart of the City
items.abstract: Since the explosion last Christmas, the city has grappled with how rebuilding will fit into its larger ambitions of transforming downtown. The hope is to draw more than just tourists.

items.title: How to Design a Home Gym That You’ll Actually Use
items.abstract: As the pandemic rages on, the safest place to work out is at home. Here’s how to create a personal gym you’ll want to spend time in.

items.title: Adrienne Adams Makes History as First Black N.Y.C. Council Speaker
items.abstract: Ms. Adams, who became speaker on Wednesday, will lead the most diverse City Council ever as New York tries to recover from the pandemic. She already faces battles with the mayor.

items.title: They Had Reasons for Leaving the City. So Why Are Their Friends Mad?
items.abstract: When Covid hit, some New Yorkers abandoned the city for good. They left some angry friends.

items.title: 19 Killed in New York City’s Deadliest Fire in Decades
items.abstract: Nine children were among those who died when a space heater malfunctioned in a Bronx apartment building, city officials said.
